case_vignette: A 32-YEAR-OLD WOMAN PRESENTS WITH AN ITCHY RASH THAT BEGAN 3 MONTHS AGO. SHE HAS A HISTORY OF ANXIETY BUT OTHERWISE NO KNOWN MEDICAL CONDITIONS. SHE HAS TRIED OVER-THE-COUNTER HYDROCORTISONE CREAM TO TREAT THE RASH, FINDING SOME RELIEF FROM THE ITCHINESS, BUT THE RASH CONTINUES TO SPREAD. SHE HAS NO KNOWN ALLERGIES AND HAS NOT CHANGED HER SKIN CARE PRODUCTS OR MEDICATIONS. ON EXAMINATION, THE PATIENT HAS DARK PURPLE AND GRAY FLAT-TOPPED PAPULES WITH FINE GRAY-WHITE STREAKS ON HER FLEXURAL WRISTS, DORSAL HANDS, ELBOWS, ANKLES, AND DORSAL FEET.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy rash that began 3 months ago and it continues to spread despite using hydrocortisone cream.
What parts of your body are affected by the rash?
The rash is on my wrists, dorsal hands, elbows, ankles, and dorsal feet.
How would you describe the appearance of the rash?
The rash has dark purple and gray flat-topped bumps with fine gray-white streaks.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin problems or other autoimmune diseases?
I don't know of any family members with similar skin problems or autoimmune diseases.
Have you started any new medications or been exposed to new substances before the rash began?
No, I have not changed my skin care products or medications.
Final Diagnosis: Lichen Planus.

The patient has no known family history of similar skin problems or autoimmune diseases. Additionally, the patient confirms that they have not made any changes to their skincare products or medications.
